name: Custom HTML & CSS UI Elements
description: Shows how to place custom HTML and CSS elements on top of ArcGIS map components to create rich, app-style interfaces. The example uses a fake property listing to demonstrate how you can display cards, labels, and modals that stay fixed above the map even when navigating in 3D. This pattern is great for small, high-value UI elements, but it’s not recommended for thousands of items due to performance limitations.

name: Use Advanced Vector Symbols to Style Lines and Polygons
description: Shows how to style a hiking trail and a lake boundary using advanced multilayer vector symbols. These symbols (CIM symbols) let you build highly customized, layered visual styles that go beyond standard line and polygon symbols. In this example, the Tahoe Rim Trail is drawn with a custom line style, and Lake Tahoe is rendered with a gradient polygon effect. CIM symbols support complex, data-driven, and even animated visualizations.

name: Community-Focused Election Tools
description: For the 2020 election Esri employees launched a community group PeopleForThePeople to build community-focused initiatives in key issues, voter resources, candidates and voter information. Learn more about the design development and integration of a wide variety of ArcGIS Solutions including ArcGIS Hub, ArcGIS StoryMaps, ArcGIS Experience Builder, ArcGIS API for JavaScript, and ArcGIS API for Python.

name: Reveal Individual Points Inside Dense Clusters (Flare Cluster)
description: Show how to display many overlapping points on a map in a clear, interactive way. Instead of collapsing nearby markers into a single dot or a simple cluster count, this example “fans out” the points in a radial pattern when a cluster is selected — letting you inspect each item individually while preserving the overall data distribution. This approach improves clarity when dealing with dense data (e.g., multiple events in the same building, many deliveries in a neighborhood, real estate listings very close to each other)..

name: Animated Vector Markers
description: Use an animated CIMSymbol to draw attention to recent earthquakes

name: Browse Indoor Maps Floor by Floor
description: Shows how to build an indoor mapping experience where users can switch between floors in a building. The sample loads an office building and lets you view each floor individually, making it easier to explore rooms, corridors, and other interior spaces. The FloorFilter automatically updates all indoor layers when a floor is selected, so the map always shows the correct level of the building.

name: Animate a Feature Service using WebGL
description: This application animates any public feature service (or service with token). Includes the ability to create an animation of a featurelayer. Animate by opacity, size (for point/line) and with a bunch of styling options. Exports canvas to .mp4 video format. Note: as it records the cavnas, we then need to ensure attribution is correctly added.

name: Clusters as pie charts (Chart-Markers)
description: This sample shows how to embed small charts directly into map markers to represent multiple data attributes per location. Instead of using simple colored dots or cluster counts, each marker includes a mini-chart (pie, donut, sparkline, bar, etc.) that visualises additional information. For example, the breakdown of event types, proportions of demographics, or trends over time. This approach makes map data more expressive and meaningful at a glance, especially when summarizing aggregated or clustered data.

name: Clusters as Bins
description: Aggregate features to bins to visualize density.

name: 2D and 3D Basemaps
description: Sample showing how to switch between a wide range of basemap styles in both 2D and 3D maps. ArcGIS provides over 50 prebuilt styles designed for different types of applications, such as highlighting boundaries, emphasizing roads, or showcasing natural terrain. All basemaps are optimized for clarity and performance and can be used directly in your projects.

name: Dots per Value in Polygons
description: Visualize the density of a population, or other count, in a polygon data layer by randomly drawing dots within polygon boundaries. Each dot represents a constant numeric value of an attribute or a subset of attributes, making it easy to compare density or distribution across regions

name: Heatmaps
description: A Heatmap renders point features as a raster surface, emphasizing areas with a higher density of points along a continuous color ramp.

name: Query Statistics by Geometry
description: Shows how to query statistics from a FeatureLayerView using a geometry, such as a buffer around a point. In this example, census tracts that intersect the buffer are analyzed to calculate population by age and gender, and the results are visualized in a population-pyramid chart. This pattern is useful for on-the-fly analysis of selected areas

name: Semi-realistic 3D scenarios
description: Visualize features with realistic WebStyleSymbols

name: Integration with Google Maps Photorealistic 3D Tiles
description: Use the ArGIS Maps SDKs to load the for Google 3D Tiles and quickly build digital twings, ....

name: Animated Crosshair Pointer
description: An interactive demo app powered by the ArcGIS API for JavaScript. Navigate with a dynamic crosshair cursor and experience smooth animations as you hover over features.

name: Real-Time Path Updates
description: Shows how to update an existing feature on the map in real time. In this example, a polyline is extended with new coordinates to show the live progression of a path, a pattern often used for tracking or streaming data sources.

name: 3D Animated Arc Lines for Origin–Destination Flows
description: Shows how to visualize origin–destination (OD) data using animated 3D arc lines. In this example, bicycle trip data from Cambridge is displayed as curved connections between start and end points, making movement patterns easy to understand at a glance. This style of visualization is commonly known as arc layers, flight paths, OD flows, spider maps, or flow lines in other mapping frameworks like deck.gl and Kepler.gl. The arcs animate to highlight direction, intensity, and overall mobility patterns.

name: Animated Lines in 2D
description: FlowRenderer with visual variables

name: Add Realistic Weather Effects to a 3D Scene
description: Shows how to use the Weather component to add clouds, rain, and other atmospheric effects to a 3D map (Scene). You can switch to a “Flooding” scenario to visualize an extreme rainfall event in Utrecht, or tweak the weather settings to create your own immersive scene.

name: Path properties
description: Path visualization in 3D

name: Spike CIM Symbols
description: Visualize 14-month of USA unemployment data at the state and county level.

name: Follow a Moving 3D Object
description: Shows how to animate a 3D object along a path and keep the camera synced with its movement. The example uses a paraglider model flying through mountain terrain to demonstrate the follow mode behavior.. To bring this visualization to life, we use the 3D paraglider model of Aaron Durogati (ITA), winner of the Red Bull X-Alps 2025.

name: Finding the nearest airports
description: Spider map using the geodeticDistanceOperator to find the 8 closes airports

name: Elevation Profile
description: Shows how to draw a path on a 3D map and instantly generate an elevation chart from it. The elevation profile is created on the client side and can be customized or integrated into your own UI or workflow.

name: Geometry projections
description: This app shows how the same geometry changes shape and position when projected into different coordinate systems. By moving a point or drawing a shape, you can see how it appears on a flat 2D map versus its real location on the 3D globe. This helps developers understand what map projections do, why distortions happen, and how reprojecting geometries lets you work with data from different sources or visualize it consistently.

name: Animated Lines in 3D
description: Shows animated flow lines on a 3D map and lets you filter what part of the data you want to display. Useful when the dataset has multiple categories or layers (called “dimensions”) and you only want to visualize specific ones.

name: Animated Lines (3D Terrain)
description: This sample displays moving flow patterns on a 3D mountain surface using the FlowRenderer on an ImageryTileLayer in a 3D scene and visualize it at different elevation modes.

name: The Globe of Extremes
description: Showing the highest and the lowest points on Earth

name: Measure Volume on 3D
description: Shows how to measure terrain volumes on a 3D map. You can draw an area, and the tool calculates how much material would need to be added or removed (cut and fill). The analysis can be created in code or interactively, and you can access the results for display or further processing.

name: Intro to popup component
description: A step-by-step guide about adding popup components to your app.

name: Display Parquet Data
description: Shows how to load and visualize a Parquet file directly on a map. Parquet is a column-oriented format used in big data and analytics, and ParquetLayer lets you render that data efficiently without converting it to another GIS format.

name: Client-side projection
description: This sample demonstrates how layers are automatically projected to a spatial reference. The sample uses a GeoJSONLayer as a custom basemap. This also demonstrates how graphics and their respective geometries can be projected to more accurately maintain shape based on the view's spatial reference by using the shapePreservingProjectOperator.

name: Display Places on a Basemap and Enrich Them
description: Shows how to display places (restaurants, cafés, parks, transit stops, etc.) on top of a basemap and retrieve additional details using the ArcGIS Places API. The demo loads place categories directly from the basemap, then fetches attributes like name, address, opening hours, or type of venue from the Places API. This pattern is useful for building local search, store locators, trip planners, or any app that needs real-world points of interest combined with map context.

name: Set a Country-Specific Worldview on a Basemap
description: Shows how to change the basemap so that country borders and labels reflect the perspective of a specific country. This is called a “worldview”. Only ArcGIS basemap styles support worldviews, and setting one adjusts how political boundaries are shown to match that country’s official view.

name: Create a Local 3D Scene
description: Shows how to build a 3D scene that is limited to a chosen area instead of the whole globe. The example loads two datasets, oil and gas wells and nearby earthquakes, and displays them both on the ground and below the surface. This lets you explore a small region in detail and visualize data above and underground in the same view.

name: Take a screenshot of a Scene
Composite views
description: Create an app with composite views

name: Disable view navigation
description: Disable all view navigation

name: Disable mouse-wheel
description: Disable mouse-wheel and single-touch navigation

name: Create a custom basemap
description: Shows how to build your own basemap by combining layers and then plug it into the Basemap Toggle component in a 3D Scene. In this example, a VectorTileLayer is loaded from a style URL and added to a new basemap’s baseLayers, allowing it to be used as an alternative basemap that users can switch to.

name: Map padding
description: Adjust the padding in the map to work with a subsection of the view

name: View event explorer / watch properties
description: Event explorer / watch properties

name: Created from array of graphics
description: Create a FeatureLayer with client-side graphics

name: Created from a shapefile
description: Create a FeatureLayer from a shapefile

name: Add or remove graphics from a FeatureLayer
Working with large feature collections
description: What to do to keep your app interactive when working with large feature collections.

name: Filter features by attributes
description: Filter features by attribute

name: Create layer from portal item
description: Create a layer from a portal item

name: Scale dependent DisplayFilter
description: Apply a scale-dependent display filter to a feature layer

name: Filter SceneLayer with time
description: SceneLayer with time filter

name: Realistic buildings
description: Realistic buildings with SceneLayer

name: Point geometries
description: Scene Layer with point geometries

name: Filter and query
description: SceneLayer filter and query

name: Slice Tool to Reveal the Inside of a 3D Building
description: Shows how to load a detailed 3D building model and use a slice tool to look inside it. The slice acts like a cutting plane that hides everything in front of it, making it easy to explore interior floors, rooms, and structural elements. You can move, resize, rotate, and tilt the slice plane, and you can choose which layers should or shouldn’t be affected by the cut. The building comes from a BIM (Revit) model published as a BuildingSceneLayer

name: Explore and Filter a 3D Building Model
description: Shows how to load a detailed 3D building model and interactively turn parts of it on or off. The example uses the BuildingExplorer component to filter floors, rooms, or structural elements so you can focus on specific parts of the building. This is useful for exploring interiors, inspecting components, or working with complex building data exported from tools like Revit.

name: CSVLayer - Project points on the fly
Intro to CatalogLayer
description: CatalogLayer in a 3D Scene

name: ImageryTileLayer raster function
description: Apply raster function to ImageryTileLayer

name: Client side pixel filter
description: ImageryLayer - client side pixel filter

name: Server side raster function
description: ImageryLayer - server side raster function

Explore a VoxelLayer using dynamic section

description: MapImageLayer - dynamic data layer with table join

description: MapImageLayer - dynamic data layer with query table

name: MapImageLayer - Explore data from a dynamic workspace
Dynamic data layer with raster data
description: MapImageLayer - raster data source

name: Select WMTS sublayer
description: Select WMTSLayer sublayer

name: Data Capture in OrientedImageryViewer

name: Toggle visualizations
description: PointCloudLayer - toggle renderers

name: Change point size and density
description: PointCloudLayer - change point size and density

name: Intensity color modulation
description: PointCloudLayer - intensity color modulation

name: Hover Interactions to a Vector Tile Layer
description: This sample shows how to implement a hover effect for features inside a vector tile layer using the ArcGIS Maps SDK for JavaScript. In this example, moving the mouse over contour lines highlights the selected line and displays its elevation, making it easy to inspect terrain details. This pattern is useful whenever you want users to interact with vector-tile features, such as street segments, boundaries, POIs, or isolines.

name: VectorTileLayer from JSON
description: VectorTileLayer - update style layers

name: VectorTileLayer - update style layers
description: VectorTileLayer - update style

name: Find the Best Order to Visit Multiple Stops
description: Shows how to compute an optimized route that reorders stops to minimize total travel time and distance. The app finds the most efficient sequence to visit multiple destinations from a starting point and can generate turn-by-turn driving directions in different languages.

name: Create Animated Pulsing Markers (WebGL)
description: Shows how to render your own WebGL objects inside a MapView by creating a custom layer and layer view. In this example, a pulsating telecom-style marker is drawn and animated directly on the GPU. Developers can plug in their own WebGL logic by subclassing Layer and BaseLayerViewGL2D to control exactly how graphics are drawn on the map.

name: Animated Lines with a Custom WebGL Layer
description: Shows how to animate polyline graphics using WebGL to create a flowing trail effect. Instead of drawing simple line segments, the sample triangulates each polyline so it can be shaded and animated directly on the GPU. This pattern is useful for visualizing movement, routes, or flow intensity with smooth, high-performance animations.

name: Tessellation helpers for custom WebGL layer views
Tiling support for custom WebGL layer views
Masking effect using a custom layer view
KnowledgeGraphLayer

name: Binning with aggregate fields
description: This sample demonstrates how to define aggregate fields that can be used in the popup, labels, and renderer of a binned layer.

description: Demonstrates how to filter binned data by category.

name: Summarize binned data using Arcade
description: Use Arcade in popups to summarize binned crimes by type

description: Aggregate polylines to bins to visualize the density of features.

description: This sample demonstrates how to summarize clustered features using charts within a cluster's popup.

description: This sample demonstrates how to aggregate polygon features to clusters.

description: Learn the basics about CIMSymbol and how to use a primitiveOverride on the text

description: Use a CIMSymbol to draw a line with arrow markers at a fixed distance

description: Visualize data with dictionary renderer

name: Polygon marker placement
description: Draw symbols in a map and adjust the CIMSymbol properties such as color, size, and marker placement.

name: Multivariate visualizations (3D)
description: Thematic multivariate visualization (3D)

name: Extrude buildings footprints based on real world heights
description: Extrude building footprints based on real world heights

name: SceneView - shadow and lighting
description: SceneView - shadow and lighting settings

name: Custom RenderNode - Crossfade slide transition
description: Custom RenderNode - Cross-fade slide transition

name: Custom RenderNode: Animate 3D Windmills with WebGL
description: Shows how to use the RenderNode API to plug custom WebGL rendering into a SceneView. A RenderNode gives low-level access to the SceneView’s WebGL context, letting you create custom 3D visualizations that behave like built-in layers. In this example, a custom RenderNode animates rotating windmills directly in the scene

name: Intro to feature effect
description: Apply featureEffect to FeatureLayer

name: Highlight feature with drop-shadow
description: Highlight a country with an effect

name: FeatureEffect - multiple effects
description: Highlight areas intersecting borough boundaries

name: FeatureEffect - drop-shadow
description: Apply drop-shadow effects to layerview

name: Highlight feature with effects and blending
Visualize historical track data
description: This sample demonstrates how to visualize hurricane data in a GeoJSONLayer as historical tracks.

name: Color Animation by Year Built
description: Shows how to use a slider to explore when New York City buildings were constructed. Each building changes color based on its construction year relative to the selected year, and a play button animates the timeline from 1880 to 2017. A bloom effect helps highlight the buildings and makes the color transitions stand out

name: Configure feature sort order
description: Learn how to configure the drawing order of features in a layer

name: Sort features by legend order
description: Control the draw order of features to match the order of unique values defined in a UniqueValueRenderer

name: Execute Arcade for a custom chart
description: Execute an Arcade expression defined in a webmap to create a custom chart

Summarize intersecting points in a popup
Create popup charts from Arcade expressions
description: This sample demonstrates how to dynamically create popup content elements using Arcade expressions.

description: Custom popup actions per feature attribute

Low poly terrain using mesh geometry
Using Esri Icon Fonts
description: Using Esri Icon Fonts with map graphics

name: Route and Directions
description: Directions component with RouteLayer

name: Search a knowledge graph
description: Search Knowledge Graphs

description: TimeSlider component and time zone

name: TimeSlider with timeOffset and actions
description: TimeSlider with timeOffset and actions

name: Geometry operator - centroid
description: Geometry operator - centroid analysis

name: Geometry operator - offset visualizer
description: Geometry operator - offset analysis

name: Geometry operator - using a worker for analysis
Viewshed Using a Geoprocessing Service
description: Shows how to call an ArcGIS Server Geoprocessing service to calculate a viewshed. Click anywhere on the map to compute which areas are visible within a 5-mile radius. The sample uses the Geoprocessor class to send the input point to the server, run the viewshed model, and display the results when they return.

name: Client-Side 3D Analysis Tools in a 3D Map
description: Shows how to create a variety of 3D analysis tools directly in a Scene component without relying on built-in UI components. The sample demonstrates how to programmatically add analyses such as area measurement, dimensions, direct line measurement, line of sight, slicing, and viewsheds. These analysis objects run fully on the client and can be added to the Scene’s analyses collection to build custom measurement or visibility workflows.

name: Visibility From Key Locations Using Slides
description: Shows how to display what can be seen from different places in a 3D scene using slides. The app loads a WebScene that already includes saved viewpoints and visibility areas, then adds a new visibility area in code. This makes it easy to compare how the view changes from landmarks, street level, or future building heights

name: Request data from a remote server
Access a secure webmap with OAuth

description: Access ArcGIS Online items using OAuth 2.0

name: Watch for component changes
description: Watch for changes in components

name: Watch for changes in components using reactiveUtils
Drag and drop portal items
description: Load portal items via drag & drop

name: Basic 2D Map with Web Components
description: Shows how to add a basic 2D map to a page using the <arcgis-map> web component. Just place the tag in your HTML and set simple attributes like center and zoom to control the view.

name: Load a Preconfigured WebMap
description: Shows how to load an ArcGIS WebMap, which is essentially a JSON configuration that defines a full map—layers, styles, popups, and initial view. Instead of building the map manually in code, you simply reference the WebMap item and the application renders everything as it was configured in ArcGIS Online or Enterprise. In this example, the WebMap visualizes accidental deaths by state using marker sizes and colors to show totals and rates.

name: Save a WebMap Configuration to Your ArcGIS Portal
description: Shows how to create a new WebMap item in ArcGIS. A WebMap is a JSON configuration that defines a complete map, and this sample demonstrates how to take that configuration and save it as an item in your Portal. Once saved, the WebMap can be reused, shared, or loaded by any application without rebuilding layers or styles manually.

name: Use Static Basemap Tiles
description: Shows how to load static basemap tiles (PNGs files). The ArcGIS Static Basemap Tiles service provides global raster basemap tiles in multiple styles. You can also set label language or worldview through customParameters to control how borders and place names appear.

name: Load a Preconfigured 3D Web Scene
description: Shows how to load a WebScene, which is a saved 3D map configuration, directly into your application. In this example, the WebScene visualizes mountain shadows around Queenstown (New Zealand) on the winter solstice. Each line in the scene marks where the mountain shadows fall at different times of the day.

name: Save a 3D WebScene to Your ArcGIS Portal
description: Shows how to take a 3D WebScene (a saved 3D map configuration) and store it in ArcGIS Online or Enterprise. You can create a brand-new WebScene item or overwrite an existing one that was previously loaded. Once saved, the WebScene can be reused or shared without rebuilding its layers, camera, or styling in code.

name: Switch Between Multiple WebMaps in One View
description: Shows how to load several WebMaps (saved map configurations) and switch between them inside the same map view. Each WebMap can have different layers, styles, and settings, and the view updates instantly when you swap the active one. This lets you reuse a single view while presenting completely different map configurations.

name: Location-allocation
description: Location-allocation is the process of finding a set of facilities that will best serve demand from surrounding areas. As the name suggests, location-allocation is a two-fold problem that simultaneously locates facilities and allocates demand points to the facilities.

name: Travel Cost Matrix
description: A travel cost matrix (also called an origin-destination or OD cost matrix) calculates the travel time or distance from many origin points to many destination points. It returns a ranked list of destinations for each origin, sorted by the lowest travel cost. This is useful for accessibility analysis, predicting travel behavior, estimating shipping costs, or providing cost inputs to other models such as linear programming or location-allocation

name: Snap to Roads
description: Use the snap to roads operation to snap GPS truck points to the nearest road. The snap to roads operation allows you to align GPS track points with the nearest routable road segments in a transportation network. The operation is designed to work with GPS data which can be imprecise. By snapping the GPS points to the nearest road segments, the operation improves accuracy of GPS data and provides a more reliable representation of the actual route taken.

name: Service Areas
description: Driving or walking time areas created for a location using the routing service. A service area, also known as an isochrone, is a polygon that represents the distance that can be reached when driving or walking on a street network. This type of analysis is common in real estate search or determining the driving proximity to schools, businesses, or other facilities. For example, you can create a drive time polygon that represents how far you can drive in any direction from the center of a city in 20 minutes.

name: Closest Facility Routing
description: Routes to the three closest facilities created with the routing service. It is the process of finding one or more nearby facilities from incidents based on travel time or travel distance. Once you've found the closest facilities, you can display the best route to them and include the travel time, travel distance, and driving directions to each facility in multiple languages

name: Last Mile Delivery
description: Geographically clustered routes generated by the Last Mile Delivery service in San Francisco, CA. Last Mile Delivery (LMD) is a type of Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP) operation that can find the most optimized routes for a fleet of vehicles that need to make deliveries. It is specifically tailored to the unique challenges of final deliveries, focusing on efficiency in dense urban environments. It produces geographically clustered routes so drivers can easily visit each location which minimizes the operating cost for the fleet of vehicles.

name: Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP)
description: Turn-by-turn directions and routes created for two trucks making six deliveries using the routing service. VRP is the process of determining the most effective routes for a set of vehicles that need to visit a set of locations. It creates the overall minimum transportation cost
